99

Your patient may be uncomfortable or upset with the

REAL questions. Use a calm tone and manner. Click

each of these patient concerns below to see what to do. You can also click to open a job aid you can print to help

you later.                                           

                                         

Addressing Concerns:

Appears Uncomfortable

Your patient may appear uncomfortable or afraid. Continue with a comforting tone and manner. Let the patient know that the data you are asking him or her to self-report will be shared only with health care providers involved in his or her care. Say something like, “We want to provide you with the best care possible. The information will be shared only within our health care organization and providers involved in your care. Your personal health information will only be shared outside of this health care facility with your permission and in accordance with state and federal privacy laws.” If the patient is still uneasy and does not want to provide any information, select “Declined.” Do not try to pressure the patient.

Addressing Concerns:

Asks Why

Sometimes, patients that are not used to these types of questions may ask why you need the information. Remember, it’s about providing great patient care. If asked, have a solid explanation handy. For example, “We use this information to help us provide better patient care and services.” If there is no need to bring up an explanation, you don’t need to offer one. It’s just good to have one ready in case you need it.

Addressing Concerns:

Unsure How to Respond

Your patient may not know how to answer the question. This could be for a number of reasons. You may want to ask where he or she is from. Once you get an answer, you can use your “Specific or Granular Categories” job aid to help the patient make the correct choice.

Addressing Concerns:

Gives Odd Answers

Your patient may be upset or anxious about why they are visiting your health care organization. He or she may provide an unusual answer, like, “I’m an American citizen,” or, “I’m a human being.” You want to give all patients the opportunity to answer the questions. When you need to, you can choose “Declined.” Use a non-confrontational approach. Take care not to push the issue if it is clear that the patient does not want to respond to the question.

Refer to the “Handling Challenging Responses” job aid for suggested responses to odd questions as well as a handy guide for addressing other challenges you might face.
